content:
Machine Learning

Machine Learning is the field of study that gives computer the capability to learn without being explicitly programmed. It works on the idea that a machine can singularly learn from the data to produce accurate results.
General tasks under machine learning:
1. Define the problem (whether it is supervised or not. Further that it is regression or classification problem)
2. Data collection
3. Visualization of data to have a basic understanding of our data
4. Train the algorithm
5. Test the algorithm
6. Compare test results to the actual results and collect feedback
7. Refine the algorithm by tuning the parameters
8. Perform steps 4-7 until the results are satisfactory 
9. Use the model to make predictions
Machine learning can be grouped into two broad learning tasks:
1. Supervised Learning : Here we specify training data along with the target(dependent variable/value to predict) into the machine 
Regression and classifications comes under supervised learning

                            
 (
Training data
)
 (
Final Model
) (
Machine
(Supervised Learning algorithm)
) Ttttbnbnmbmnv  
                                                                                                      
                                                                                                               
 (
Target Variable
)
                                                     



Regression: When the target variable/dependent variable is continuous value it is a regression problem.
For example:  predicting stock value, amount of rain happen next day, predicting profit and so on
Regression algorithms:
· Simple linear regression 
· Multiple linear regression
· Polynomial regression
· Decision Trees
· Random forest
· Support vector regressor

Classification: When the target variable is a categorical value it is a classification problem. For example: whether stock will rise or fall, whether it will rain or not etc.


Classification algorithms:
· Logistic regression
· K Nearest Neighbors’(KNN)
· Decision Trees
· Random forest
· Naïve Bayes
· Support vector classifier


2. Unsupervised learning: Here we just provide the training data and not the target variable. Machine itself learns the data and predict the categories on its own. 
Clustering, recommender systems comes under unsupervised learning.
 (
Final model
) (
Unsupervised machine learning models
) (
Training data
)
                                                                                                                                



Clustering: put data into some groups called clusters such that each cluster contains data with similar characteristics (as determined by the model, not in advance by humans)
Clustering example : Customer segmentation based on their age and salary

Clustering algorithms: 
· K-means clustering
· Hierarchical clustering 

Simple Linear regression: statistical measure to analyze bivariate linear relationship.
Equation:
	Y = MX + C
Y: dependent or target variable to be predicted by the model
M: slope of the line
X: Independent variable
C: constant (point where the line cuts the y-axis)


Linear regression assumptions:
Following assumptions must be fulfilled before applying linear regression model –
1. Linear relationship
2. Multivariate normality
3. No or little multicollinearity 
4. No auto-correlation
How models works:
Linear regression model tries to fit a linear line in the given data points until it finds a best fitted line.
A best fitted line is that line which has minimum OLS (ordinary least square value) among all the lines


Graph plotted for Experience(X) vs Salary(Y)
Algorithm:
# import libraries
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from pandas import Series,DataFrame
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# loading data
data=pd.read_csv('Salary_Data.csv')
# data preprocessing
data.isnull().any()
data.columns
x=data[['YearsExperience']]
y=data.iloc[:,1]

#splitting data into training and test data
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
x_train,x_test,y_train,y_test=train_test_split(x,y,test_size=0.3,random_state=0)

# creating linear regressor model
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
regressor=LinearRegression()

Machine Learning

Machine Learning is the field of study that gives computer the capability to learn without being explicitly programmed. It works on the idea that a machine can singularly learn from the data to produce accurate results.
General tasks under machine learning:
1. Define the problem (whether it is supervised or not. Further that it is regression or classification problem)
2. Data collection
3. Visualization of data to have a basic understanding of our data
4. Train the algorithm
5. Test the algorithm
6. Compare test results to the actual results and collect feedback
7. Refine the algorithm by tuning the parameters
8. Perform steps 4-7 until the results are satisfactory 
9. Use the model to make predictions
Machine learning can be grouped into two broad learning tasks:
1. Supervised Learning : Here we specify training data along with the target(dependent variable/value to predict) into the machine 
Regression and classifications comes under supervised learning

                            
 (
Training data
)
 (
Final Model
) (
Machine
(Supervised Learning algorithm)
) Ttttbnbnmbmnv  
                                                                                                      
                                                                                                               
 (
Target Variable
)
                                                     



Regression: When the target variable/dependent variable is continuous value it is a regression problem.
For example:  predicting stock value, amount of rain happen next day, predicting profit and so on
Regression algorithms:
· Simple linear regression 
· Multiple linear regression
· Polynomial regression
· Decision Trees
· Random forest
· Support vector regressor

Classification: When the target variable is a categorical value it is a classification problem. For example: whether stock will rise or fall, whether it will rain or not etc.


Classification algorithms:
· Logistic regression
· K Nearest Neighbors’(KNN)
· Decision Trees
· Random forest
· Naïve Bayes
· Support vector classifier


2. Unsupervised learning: Here we just provide the training data and not the target variable. Machine itself learns the data and predict the categories on its own. 
Clustering, recommender systems comes under unsupervised learning.
 (
Final model
) (
Unsupervised machine learning models
) (
Training data
)
                                                                                                                                



Clustering: put data into some groups called clusters such that each cluster contains data with similar characteristics (as determined by the model, not in advance by humans)
Clustering example : Customer segmentation based on their age and salary

Clustering algorithms: 
· K-means clustering
· Hierarchical clustering 

Simple Linear regression: statistical measure to analyze bivariate linear relationship.
Equation:
	Y = MX + C
Y: dependent or target variable to be predicted by the model
M: slope of the line
X: Independent variable
C: constant (point where the line cuts the y-axis)


Linear regression assumptions:
Following assumptions must be fulfilled before applying linear regression model –
1. Linear relationship
2. Multivariate normality
3. No or little multicollinearity 
4. No auto-correlation
How models works:
Linear regression model tries to fit a linear line in the given data points until it finds a best fitted line.
A best fitted line is that line which has minimum OLS (ordinary least square value) among all the lines
